abstract.p: Ken Johnson reviews Innuendo, show of understated eroticism by 13 artists, at Dee/Blasoe gallery (S)

block.p: True to its title, ''Innuendo,'' one of the better group shows of the moment, generates a compelling ambience of understated eroticism. The 13-artist roster, selected by a painter, Doug Wada, includes mostly familiar names but a refreshingly diverse range of images and ideas.

The centerpiece is a massive double bed boxed in by beautifully carved Gothic Revival-style panels by Brian Tolle. With padded leather prayer kneelers installed around its base, it slyly marries the sacred and the profane.

True to its title, ''Innuendo,'' one of the better group shows of the moment, generates a compelling ambience of understated eroticism. The 13-artist roster, selected by a painter, Doug Wada, includes mostly familiar names but a refreshingly diverse range of images and ideas.

The centerpiece is a massive double bed boxed in by beautifully carved Gothic Revival-style panels by Brian Tolle. With padded leather prayer kneelers installed around its base, it slyly marries the sacred and the profane.

Images of women as objects of mystery and desire recur, but always with a twist. They include a yearbook-style portrait of a winsomely vacant girl by John Currin; intertwined female legs in a snappy, Pop-style gouache by John Wesley; a giant black-and-white head of a beautiful woman with huge eyes strangely rendered in color by Richard Phillips. Dana Hoey, in turn, cleverly plays on the male gaze in a photograph resembling an Abercrombie & Fitch advertisement that updates the Judgment of Paris.

Same sex desire is slyly implied in Felix Gonzalez-Torres's image of a pair of chairs printed on a jigsaw puzzle, Collier Schorr's photograph of boy wrestlers and, perhaps, Mr. Wada's iconic painting of a pair of red gym locker doors.

A short digitized video by Shannon Kennedy is not explicitly erotic but is enthralling nevertheless. Shown on a small DVD screen, the four-minute loop gives us the wandering, camera-eye view of someone getting on and off a subway. It pauses over the interaction of a young man and his girlfriend, but it is the slowly streaming, slightly jerky sensuality of the whole that captivates.
